title: Thrust bearing base for MeArm V0.4

description.text:
To address slop issues in the MeArm base, here is a new base for the MeArm V0.4 utilizing a 65mm O.D. x 45mm  I.D. x 5mm thrust bearing. I ordered one from ebay for 4 dollars. This base replaces the original square one attached to the top of the (4) M3 x 20mm bolts.  
Also included is a dxf file that has been cleaned up (The original v0.4 dxf uses splines instead of lines and arcs. Ugh!) and re-nested to fit on an 8 1/2" x 11" sheet for us American folk. No other changes were made. It is version "0.4.A" (American)

This mounts fits the FLIR Ax5 Series of compact thermal cameras, and lets them attach to a 1/4"-20 thread.
Put a quarter inch/20 helicoil in the mounting hole, and use four M3-10mm screws to mount to the camera.

title: Screwdriver handles for magnetic chuck, storage.

description.text:
Handle for a 1/4" (6.35mm) hex magnetic chuck. I found something similar here on Thingiverse, but the hex slot was only deep enough for a bit; I made this one deep enough for the full shaft of the magnetic chuck, so it doesn't wobble.
Versions:
ScrewdriverStor.stl: Compact, with no magnet. It's the length of the chuck itself.
ScrdvStrLngF2.stl: Long, with magnet. The magnet is exposed at both ends, so it comes into contact with the chuck whether it's in use or stored.
ScrdvStrLngF3.stl Sames as above,but put some supports in the model to print bottom-up; your printer might not need them.
That rounded end sure adds a lot of triangles!
I put 5mm at the end of the handle so you can rap it against a tabletop to easily extract the chuck in storage.

I built this on my Makerbot Replicator 2 (retrofitted with HBP) with 2 shells and 75% fill, 0.3mm layer height, extruder at 240C.  Too many shells can create voids in the end where it contacts the build plate.  The walls of the chuck and the magnet are pushed out by 0.5mm, to allow for slop; your mileage may vary.  Larger extruders may require expansion, tighter ones may contraction.  Only X-Y stretch/shrink to do this; the Z heights are good.  The magnet is a 3/16" (4.76mm) cylinder.  To insert the magnet, I centered it on the hex end of the chuck and just pushed it into place.  It fits snugly  enough that I can't pull it out either side.

The Olimyoo are large, four-armed humanoids with tough gray-green skin and pachyderm-like features. Olimyoo in Nexus City are likely escapees from Tartaran enslavement.  
Peaceful creatures by nature, the Olimyoo have the distinction of coming from the planet, Pakinare, a world in a distant universe with a 78% compatibility with Earth biology. It is widely assumed that the Children of Tartarus found this world by means of magical scrying while searching for a new home after their separation from the Galactic Neo-Roman Empire.  
The language of the Olimyoo is best described as being musical in nature. Olimyoo are incapable of speaking other languages, though may learn and comprehend them.  
Olimyoo concepts by Jeremy Larsen, model designed in Sculptris and TinkerCAD.
Printed at 10% infill at a .10 layer height. Assembled with superglue and painted with model acrylics.

This is a case for the LCV lead acid battery desulphator unit which is based on an original circuit designed and published by Alastair Couper in the American HomePower magazine in 2000, see http://www.homepower.com/view/?file=HP77_pg84_Couper . A kit for this unit is available here: http://www.courtiestown.co.uk/index.php/battery-desulphators/kits/12v-lvc-basic-kit.html
A full description of the unit is available here: http://www.courtiestown.co.uk/media/custom/upload/File-1401097440.pdf I have added a "window" so you can see the LED better. This works well if your PLA is somwhat transparent (most PLAs are). On the LVC desulphator circuit itself, it really works very well as far as I can tell. For good effect, it really should be left connected to the battery for many days. I have always disconnected it from the car circuit, and added a trickle charger to avoid draining the battery.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: If you have problems with warping, a brim support can be useful. I printed in PLA, but I see no reason why not ABS would also work.

Very straight ahead print.   
The case is snap fit, but you can add two M3 countersunk screws by breaking the thin layer covering them in the base.

EDIT: I was still getting some tangling with this spool holder. Sideways spool holders lend themselves from separating from the back of the printer, and then occasionally if the print head moves all the way to the front, and then all the way to the back, the released tension will cause the filament to wrap around the holder. I'm still going to leave the files up, but I'd strongly recommend moving to either of these straight-feed holders: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:722110 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:493912 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668660 This is a remix of the 72mm spool holder. I bought some spools from eBay, and the other spool holder wasn't wide enough. This spool holder seemed to be the best design for the Da Vinci (aside from the DIY one that goes inside the printer), so I made it compatible with very wide spools. When you install the spool on the Da Vinci 1.0, be sure to set the spool to unravel from the side of the closest outside wall. If the spool unravels from the middle of the printer, you will get jams due to the spool unraveling too much. Also, remove any caps that come with the eBay spools. Those will not fit with them on. Update: With this remix I had experimented with making the filament guide that was built into the spool holder thinner in hopes of decreasing friction. It does not work (it did not work on the original model either), the filament guide "grabs" onto the filament too much and causes too much strain for the print head. Do not use the filament guide built into the holder. Just feed the filament through the gap in the printer, and then through the Da Vinci PTFE tube.

Made with 0.3mm layer height and 15% hexagon infill with 3 exterior layers.  Plenty strong.  
And, of course, if you're printing with ABS (you have a da vinci so you probably are), resize by 101% to account for ABS shrinking.  
Finally, apply a 180 degree rotation along the X or Y axis if you want the spool holder to be flat with the surface.  Supports are still required for printing the gap.

A gear which captures the hex nuts for bed levelling on the Printrbot Jr.

V1
My printer wasn't fully calibrated at the time I made these, so I had to print them with a 10mm hex nut width to fit the 8mm hex nuts supplied with the Printrbot Jr. The (V1) .stl file has a 10mm hex nut hole that I printed, but other size hex nut gears can be exported from the SketchUp file where I have included multiple hex nut sizes which can be made by pulling the relevant faces to zero (this will be clearer when you see the file). V2
I revisited this model after learning how to use OpenSCAD and made a parametric version. I didn't bother uploading the .scad file as it relies on an external .dxf file, rather than a math library to produce the gear shape. This version should fit the standard PBJ hex nuts nicely and should also print with a circular hole in the base rather than just a "hex lip" around the nut.

comments.text: Not necessarily... If the adjustments are fairly minor (i.e. only a couple of mm) then the act of levelling the region above the adjustment screw fixes a point on a plane. By fixing a the four corners of the bed, you effectively level the whole thing, assuming that your bed is not bowed in some way. Ideally you should use three points at the edge of the largest equilateral triangle you can fit on your bed rather than 4 points at the corners, but this would be a bit of a rework for the Printrbot.

title: TARDIS with Light and Sound FX

description.text:
I really liked Captain Spatula's Deluxe TARDIS design but I wanted the lights to pulse and I wanted to add sound, I also only had 3mm LEDs on hand. I've remade some of the parts, specifically the following: Note you'll need to download the parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124033 first, if you have the 5mm LEDs then the only custom part you need from mine is the battery holder. LED Holder - Redesigned for 3mm LEDs
Lamp Shade - Redesigned for 3mm LEDs
Battery Holder - Redesigned to allow an Arduino Pro Mini Clone (the ebay ones) to fit as well as added a ledge for a speaker to rest on. The power consumption is pretty low, the initial sequence is around 60mA then after it should be down around 40mA
The Arduino code is pretty simple, this was actually my first Arduino project so the code may not be completely optimized but it seems to work well. It uses the tone library to play the Doctor Who intro theme, then the lights turn on and for the first 3 cycles of the light dimming the speakers emit a tone that follows the light (a crude simulation of the takeoff sound) then the speaker mutes and the light keeps pulsing. Video link https://youtu.be/8yTFDHHQFvE

WARNING: Code bug causes sound to reactivate after ~17 minutes, I believe this is because my counter variable is rolling over to -37,768, I need to fix the code. Hopefully between the schematic and broadboard images as well as the comments in the code there is enough info for others to make this. If you're new to arduino I recommend first going through this tutorial on fading an LED
https://opensourcehardwaregroup.com/tutorial-10-fade-an-led-with-pulse-width-modulation-using-analogwrite/
Then to get a handle on the sound part go through this one:
http://arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/Tone
My code is really just a mashup of the two :) Materials:
3D printer to print the TARDIS parts
Arduino Pro Mini Clone 5V (any arduino should work though)
5 white LEDs, 3mm
2 360ohm resistors
1 100ohm resistor
1 8ohm or 16ohm speaker (I used one salvaged from a audio birthday card)
9V Battery
9V Battery leads
Wire
Glue Gun or double sided tape Tools:
Soldering Iron
Voltmeter (Optional)

author: 1ef84ca

title: PrintrBot Plus 2.1 Dual Alu Extruder System

description.text:
These parts are to provide the means of mounting two PrintrBot Alu direct drive extruders to a PrintrBot Plus version 2.1 (1311) though it may work on older printers. This does not work for any Plus with the X-Z upgrade; I intend to do that to my printer in the future and then create a derivative of this for a X-Z upgraded Plus.  
It also has plenty of 40 mm fan mounting places for cooling: 2 to cool the motor in the back, 2 to cool the alu extruder pieces, 2 to cool the ubis extruder, and 2 to cool the print job. You obviously don't NEED most of these but the holes are there for you to use. It also has slots to hold the M3 nuts for some of the fan mounts to make your job easier. It is easy to convert the design to use a single 80 mm for the alu extruder parts and the motor but I'm trying to keep the weight down by using 40 mm.  
All the little 2-4 mm tall raised slots around the edges are for zip-ties to keep wires nice and tidy, something I'm always a huge fan of.  
This will cause you to lose roughly 20 mm of X axis movement since it is wider to accommodate the 2nd extruder. You must program your max movement to be around 180 mm on the X axis.  
The extruder offset is 37 mm on the X axis. This means its 37 mm from the center of the left extruder (extruder 1) to the center of the right extruder (extruder 2).  
It is 17.45 mm to the center of the extruders from the 'support wall' along the Y axis. When I say 'support wall', I'm referring to the vertical wall behind the extruders where you mount the linear bearing sleeves. For reference, the center of the original wood based extruder is 15.76 mm and the center of the PrintrBot designed single Alu extruder is 17.4 mm both from the same wall.  
You will likely want to slow down the printer with all this as the extra weight of a 2nd extruder + motor + hot end will make it shake more than it does. I've been able to print at 75 mm / s without issue but I don't see a point in going faster.  
I always print all my printer parts out of ABS (because I don't have nylon or other more exotic filaments) and have the infill around 50% or higher. PLA may not like the temperatures the motors or hot end can get to when printing using this system.  
I used four M3 15mm nylon stand-offs to mount the ExtrudrBoard next to the PrintrBoard within the boxed area in the bottom. There should be already-existing holes for it but I only used two of them as the other two would interfere with the y-axis belt system. The other two stand-offs were just to help maintain strength with plugging cables into the board.  
You will likely have to re-flash the firmware on your Printrboard for it to print. My bot came flashed with firmware for 3 extruders and it would give Min Temp errors when I plugged in the ExtrudrBoard until I reflashed firmware set to two extruders.  
I'm going to include the .hex file for the PrintrBoard firmware. It is pre-configured with a max X-Axis of 183 and set for dual Extruders. The PID's are set to what I use and they may be different for you. I also use M8 threaded rods for my Z-Axis so the Z-Axis steps may not be correct for you. I'm also including the SketchUp file for anyone who wants to modify it.?

Print one of each of the 6 objects included in ABS or equally temperature resistant filament. PLA likely won't be able to handle the heat generated by the two extruders. I recommend setting your vertical and horizontal walls to be at least 1 mm thick (I used 1.2 mm) and having at least 50% infill (I used 75%). You shouldn't need supports but you can use them if you want. The longest overhangs are for the zip ties, which are 5mm long overhangs. Bill of Materials - Most of this comes from the original Plus 2.1 Extruder mount system
Large Parts:
  • 1x PrintrBot ExtrudrBoard (with ribbon cable)
  • 2x Nema 17 Large Kysan Motors
  • 2x Alu Extruder (or 3D printed equivalent)
  • 2x Ubis Hot Ends (Metal Ubis may work but not tested)
  • 0-8x 40 mm fan(s), recommend at least 4: 2 to cool off the back of the motors and 2 to cool off the print job
    • For Structure:
  • 2x Press Fit Bearing Sleeve
  • 8x M4-10 Screws
  • 9x .5" 6-32 Screws
  • 9x 6-32 Nuts*
  • 2x M3-12 Screws
  • 2x M3 Lock Nuts
    • For Belt Tension:
  • 2x Thumb Screws*
  • 2x M3 Lock Nuts
    • To put it together, its mostly self explanatory. I ended up not using the hot end cooling fans so I put the hot end cables going out through the fan holes.

description.text: This is the circuit board mount I designed for my Anti/Social Lights project. It's supposed to mount a circuit board in the center of a hollow plastic ball.

Once upon a time, the original clips that held a faceplate to the cabinet in our bathroom broke. I'd tried designing and printing off a replacement back in my early MakerBot Cupcake days, but it didn't quite work out. I finally got around to redesigning it in OpenSCAD, printing off a pair and re-installing that faceplate. Source files can be found at GitHub:
https://github.com/clothbot/makerbot/tree/master/fabjects/Household/FaceplateClip

• Open the source file in OpenSCAD, tweak as required and render. Export as STL.
  • Print off two (or more) pairs.
  • Use double-sided tape to do the initial positioning of the parts.
  • Screw them in place. The screw holes are sized to be 1/8" wide.
  • Re-install faceplate.

Combine a Nexus 7 (2013) with a Symbol LS3408 laser barcode scanner.

Remove the screws from the scanner and remove the circuit board.  Solder a usb cable to the back of the RJ50 connector and re-assemble the the scanner running the usb cable through the top of the scanner.  The original screws can be used to connect the scanner to the printed tablet back.  Connect the male end of the usb cable to a USB OTG cable and stuff the cable/connectors in the printed tablet back.  Use a screen protector, and 2.2 mm craft foam all around the tablet to protect from shock/abrasion.  Use screws to attach the printed halves together.

A demon baby that you can print to this world. Don't be afraid when it opens its eyes. Your wife wants a child?
Your mother wants a grandchild?
Your daughter wants a little brother?
  • Print a demon baby!
    • Easy to take care of. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QnT25DRmQ2Q

• Drinks only blood
  • Feed with meat daily
  • Violently shake it when it screams
  • Keep it hot around it
    • You need to print 1 body, 4 eye lids and 2 eyes. Put everything in a pot and then shake. Alternatively put the parts together by hand:
  • First put in the lower eye lids by putting the thingy sticking out at the side of the lid into the hole in the side of the eye socket. Then press in the other side.
  • All eyelids are the same but the edge with a bit sticking out needs to be pointing to the outside of the eye socket.
  • Putting in the 2nd eyelid is a bit harder but works with force.
  • Lastly put the eyes in, again with some force.
    • The tongue can just be put in the mouth alternatively.

title: E3D Cyclops and Chimera mounts for Rostock Max

description.text:
Update 11/15/2015
  • Design is no longer a work in progress.
  • Thickened all mounting flanges on side mount designs for added stiffness.
  • Uploaded STEP files for all models including master assembly.
  • Added one new design with the input from user BigMike609. This design is a centered side mount design that hangs from under the platform. The benefit of this is that you get the stiffness of the side mount designs AND can use either the Cyclops or Chimera hot ends. This is the design I will be using from here on out. Thanks for the suggestion Mike!
    • Original Text All 3 designs that I am working on feature a hole for wiring that will allow a 2-pin XT60 connector to pass through and are described in more detail below.

  • Side Mount (centered)
    This is for the cyclops only because the heater blocks for the chimera won't fit inside the circle of the platform. This mount places the nozzle in the center of the platform. Centering the nozzle offsets the heater block to one side. Minimum clearance between heater and platform is 1.3mm.

  • Side Mount (offset)
    This is also a cyclops-only mount. It centers the heater block in the platform which offsets the nozzle by 3mm in Y. Minimum clearance between heater and platform is 2.7mm.

  • Top Mount
    This is a top mount adapter that allows use of both cyclops and chimera, but loses some Z-height. The reason it is stepped rather than flat is so that you can still use platform LED rings and it should add some stiffness. This is the only design that will require support material.

description.text: Looking through thingiverse I see many of you are using nuts and bolts and other things in your designs. I used this demo piece to show that it can be used as a decent bearing, and that you can weld it with an extruder.

Print out all the parts. I'm using a printerbot and found that 4mm holes in my model turn into 3mm holes in reality, so you may have to adjust for that. Assemble according to the youtube video here:
http://youtu.be/E5XLjEbcVVQ Check out more information about how any I made it on :
www.trenchPhysics.com

author: jrombousky

description.text: Replacement gears for a Roomba 581. But it should fit lot's of other models, too.

I finally designed all gears because I found out that none of my original gears were in perfect shape anymore. The OpenSCAD file gives you the opportunity to tweak some design parameters.
Keep in mind that 2 of the gears need an metal axle of about 7 mm length and 3 mm diameter. I glued them inside with a drop of super glue. The code is of poor quality. Just a mashup of two libraries and some new lines of code. You should be able to tweak some parameters if necessary. I recommend to use something else than PLA as material for the small motor gear. During longer operation the motor heats up. When it reaches the glass temperature of PLA the axis begins to slip and the gear wores out. Maybe one gets better results with Nylon or HIPS. The other gears are still in a good shape. Even after longer operation. Used code from following things
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:268787
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021
Many thanks to their creators.

comments.text: That's a good advice to use helical gears. But currently I use a Neato Botvac. So I have no platform to test some optimized gears. Maybe someone else finds the time to model and test them.

It would be nice to model these with helical instead of straight gears. This would make the whole mechanism quieter. This is what iRobot has done with the 880 and higher models. This has made the unit significantly quieter, especially the side brush. I have actually replaced my side brushes on the 770 with the 880 model for that specific reason.

comments.author: ComedianCosplayer

comments.text: The pieces should fit together easily but without any play.  If your printed dimensions do not match the model, check to make sure your printers firmware is calibrated properly.  Use a digital caliper to verify dimensions.
comments.author: ComedianCosplayer

comments.text: Also, verify your slicer calibrations.  Slicers that don't print perimeters before shells can print holes smaller than they should be.  Cura prints shells before the perimeter, so holes may be too small, if not carefully calibrated.  Skeinforge (SFact) can be set up to print in the order you want it, but only prints from one extruder.  It also takes a long time to process the slices, but produces better looking results that Cura.  I think Kisslicer can be set to print perimeters first as well.  I've read that Kisslicer is one of the best slicers out there, but the free version will only print from one extruder and only one model at a time.  Currently it is $42 US for the full version.
comments.author: ReallyBigTeeth

description.text:
UPDATE - 2013/06/16 If you have an Ultimaker, upgrade to Cura 13.06 or newer!
NOTE: It is a closed beta right now, so you will have to hunt for the link. I will not be posting it because of it's status. UPDATE - 2013/06/15 Alpha 1.8.1:
  • Resized form to fit smaller screens; the next major release will have a resizable form.
  • BUG: STLs are being created with a zero height base in some cases. This is NOT fixed in this revision.
    • UPDATE - 2013/04/14 Alpha 1.8:
  • Windows XP Support
  • Added Resolution Limiter
  • UI Improvements
  • New Anti-Spike Features

Let me start by saying this is an Alpha! There are features missing and known bugs (specifically in surface duplication). I saw a stamp maker the other day but it was Mac only (OmNomNom - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24639), and the author didnâ€™t want to translate it, so, I made one over the weekend! I plan to add RGB control, a blur function, additional surface optimizations and an option to smooth high boarders (very useful in B/W [stamp] mode). Tell me what you think! Is there something out there that is better than what I have scrapped together? Have fun!

I have attached a ZIP of Alpha 1.5. The source is available under GPL3 from its GIT hub:
https://github.com/BloodBlight/ImageToSTLConverter It requires Windows and .NET.

comments.text: have you tired inkscape?  once you import an image you can RC on it and click "trace bitmap" or shift+Alt+B which brings up the trace tool. make sure to select the bottom button "live preview" so you can see the image getting manipulated. You'll have to play around with "edge detection" "invert image" how many colors you have it scan for etc. This is very useful for extruding text and or other shapes etc. Think of it as a 2D to 3D converter but in order to smooth/round/bend corners further editing is required. Once you get the image Solid Black (this is what will be extruder in the Z axis plane unless you want a hollow look then the opposite is true making an outline of the image) you'll hit "ok". Close that bitmap trace window and the newly created image path will now be on the main inkscape canvas and it should be selected by default. you NEED to make sure you delete the original imported image leaving the bitmap traced path image only! NOW your're nearly done. By default the newly generated bitmap trace image wont be fitting inside the somewhat small black outlined window which is KEY for a successful .SVG export. To easily do this use control+shift+D for document properties and select "Resize page content" and select "resize page to drawing or selection" now youll see the new bitmap trace image is place inside the black outlined window on the canvas. Youre ready to go to save as...Now you have an .SVG for CNC,Laser engraving and easily can be converted to .obj or .stl by simply imported the .SVG file into Tinkercad.  Hope this helps someone as it took me some time to figure this process out myself :)

• Max Res helps keep the file size down. Unless you are having slicing issues or are running out of RAM, it should be fine at the defaults.
    • The Spike/Anti-Spike filter cunts down on single/multiple pixel variants that while more true to the image will cause the print to degrade because of the nature of additive printers. Basicly, if there is a single pixel "above" the pixels around it, should it be removed to prevent an unnecessary and ugly "dot" (and sometimes string) on the top most layer of your print.

comments.text:
If you set the "Add to Base" to 0.5 (minimum thickness), and a target high to 1, it will make cool lithophanes. See: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:39457http://www.thingiverse.com/mak... Be sure to print with 100% infil for lithophanes with retraction turmed on, and have you Z as small as it will go (in my case, 0.05MM).
They don't look like much until you hold them to the light, then they come to life. That would be a situation where you would put in a family photo or such.
However if you want make a structure, you can feed it an image using brightness as a Z scale. A base would be just that, a base to add on even when the height is zero, and the target height would be the range from black to white. Thicker prints would be good for things like topographical maps.
The RGB allows for the selection or color channels. For example, I was trying to print three lithophanes from the same image; one in each color. Then combine them to make a full color lithophane. It didn't work out, but the functions are still there.
B/W mode would be good for making ink stamps, or cookie cutters.
The alpha channel is used for image formats that have transparency. That is harder to explain without more time.
The preview window is a representation of height. Black being the thickest (blocking more light), white being the thinnest (allowing more through).
If I ever do all the things I said I was going to do with this, I will be sure to add tooltips to it! :)

author: NicholasF

description.text:
At the dawn of 3d printing, I was inspired by Adrian Bowyers' ideas, so I -- and a host of others -- purchased a Rapman kit from bitsfrombytes to join the revolution. (That, of course, was the precise instant everything went wrong.) Now, years later, I am attempting to convert that useless cube into a franken-Mendel, posting whatever custom prints I make to do so.  
A work-in-progress, obviously.  I am testing all parts before I post them however.  
[edit] Gearing up for 1.0 soon!

As always, I post the SCAD files on bld34: http://www.bld3r.com/obj/5899501847969792 Frame: Completely made from Rapman 8mm threaded rods, and tricolor-Mendel vertex corners. Some time was spent with a hacksaw to shorten 2. Z-axis Motor Mounts: Designed a NEMA-23 motor holder instead of the Mendel's NEMA-17. The motor had to be rotated slightly to fit. (Yes, I know the motors need to point down. The ones pictured are double-ended.) zholder-nema23.stl Y-axis motor mount:
  • 2 x ymount-23.stl
    • Y-axis rods: Bigger frame clamps were needed to attach the Rapman's 12mm Y-axis rods. frameclip-12mm.stl Linear bearing clips: Larger-bore clips for the Rapman's 12mm-inner-diameter linear bearings. Updated for a looser fit and more rational measurements (30mm everythings!) y-bearing-clip-2.stl Horizontal shaft drive:
  • Three bevel gears with setscrew
  • One bevel gear without setscrew, to sit on stepper
  • 2 x shaft-holder.stl to attach to excess threaded rod
  • bearing-nema23.stl, to go where the motor used to be and hold a skateboard bearing
  • bearing-top.stl to attach to bearing-nema23.stl with spacers and another bearing
  • springs, washers, nuts, threaded rods
    • X and Y axis limit switches: They are different due to the X needing to fit on 8mm rods, the Y needing to fit on 12, and both needing to fit the big beefy switches the Rapman used.
  • 8mm-limit.stl
  • 12mm-limit.stl
    • Z axis mounts: Three big pieces to fit the left side, right side and motor, and the slide and bearings.
  • xz-carrier.stl : Carries the X axis motor
  • z-slider.stl: Other side of the X axis, to hold rods and bearings
  • x-slide4-e3d.stl: Slides on the 12mm rod with rapman linear bearings. It has little arms to hold something like an E3D extruder. It has been redesigned to be sturdier, smaller, and include a 40mm fan on the back, ducted over the heatsink. Use the plus8 one if you have an x-brand e3d that's extra tall.
  • proboscis.stl : A little square that fits on the front of the x-slide to aim cooling air downwards after it passes through the heatsink, for permanently-wired bed cooling.
    • Z-axis belt: Uses the 5mm belt from the rapman. Not quite ideal but whatever works.
  • T5-8-pulley.stl: Sticks formly onto a stepper motor shaft with flat.
  • tension-arm.stl: Pivots on the bolts holding the X-axis stepper motor, to press on the X belt and give it tension. One 608 bearing fits inside.
  • tension-arm-cap.stl: Something to glue onto the tension arm so it holds the bearing and the belt securely.
    • Other things: Will be posted when I get to them.

comments.text: looking good, ive just been given a defunct Rapman 3.2, and was planning on fixing it by replacing the electronics, as the hardware seems good. would you recommend doing this conversion, and do you have any advice on working on the Rapman. Im new to 3d printers but have some experience in this sort of thing.

comments.text: You may be able to squeeze some use out of it if you got a RAMPS kit -- that is, an Arduino Mega board, a RAMPS shield, and 3 or 4 stepper motor controllers.  That should completely replace all the electronics except the power supply, for which a decent ATX power supply of 500 watts and up would serve.  The usual program to install on a RAMPS setup is Marlin, which will take more explaining than I can do in one post here since it needs to be fine-tuned heavily, but the #reprap channel on freenode has always been extremely helpful to me for that.

English:
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:636591 I created my own race-chassis for the hubsan X4 (first generation, with only 2 LEDs) with 7mm motors.
The chassis, printed in PLA, weights ~8.5gr, what is nearly the same weight than the original chassis. With a stripped Keycam (http://www.chucklohr.com/808/index.shtml) and a 380mAh-battery, the complete copter is about pretty good flying 43gr. v2-Changes:
After a few flights and crashes, I decided to do some minor changes, to add more stability. Also I tried to keep the weight. The v2 has strenghten connections between the arms and the body. German:
Als ich http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:636591 gesehen hatte hab ich ein ähnliches Race-Chassis für den alten Hubsan X4 (der ohne LEDs in den Auslegern) mit 7mm Motoren entworfen. Das Chassis wiegt aus PLA gerade einmal 8,5 Gramm, etwa genau so viel wie das originale Gehäuse. Mit einer billigen China-Keycam (http://www.chucklohr.com/808/index.shtml) und einem 380mAh Akku wiegt der Copter fulgfertig ca 43 Gramm. Damit lässt er sich noch toll fliegen. v2-Änderungen:
Nach einigen Flügen und Abstürzen entschied ich mich, den Rahmen noch etwas zu verstärken, ohne das Gewicht zu sehr zu erhöhen. V2 hat nun stärkere Verbindungen vom Mittelteil zu den Auslegern.

remixed_from.title: iPhone5/4 in Otterbox Defender + Anker Astro E3 "Ingress Pack"

title: Ingress Pack -- iPhone 6 Plus in Otterbox Defender / Anker Astro E3 combination clip

description.text: This is an easy-to-hold (with hand strap) all-in-one phone/external-battery-pack combo for playing Ingress without power worries. The phone snaps out easily (just like removing it from the Otterbox belt clip) when you don't need the battery. This clamps an Anker Astro E3 battery to the back of an iPhone 6 Plus in an Otterbox Defender series case. It is a remix of my iPhone 4/5 ingress pack (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:593818) modified to accommodate an iPhone 6 Plus. The iPhone/battery combination can be snapped into the original Otterbox belt clip, however (unlike the iPhone 4/5 belt clip) it requires removing a little plastic from the holster to make the two indentations a little deeper to allow clearance for the "hooks" (see photos). I used a Dremel grinding wheel; you don't have to remove much; about 2mm. I use a 12-inch velcro "cable tie" for a hand strap; it fits through the slot in the main clip. See the remix things for more information, such as battery and lightning cable details/links.

The main clip needs to print with support.  There are two versions; each with the logo of one of the factions.  Choose wisely...  
Even with the "ears" on the battery bracket part, I still had one end start lifting off the build plate part way through printing.  For the second print, I dabbed some acetone on the ears' perimeter with a Qtip to make sure they stuck to the print bed; that did the trick.  
The "button" part is optional; it snaps into (the battery side of) the battery bracket; it should be loose, but not fall out; it allows pressing the battery's status button while mounted in the clip.

title: K-Cup Holder Suitable for printing on Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I liked the design of the original, but the first ring was over sized for printing on the Simple Metal even with no skirt, so I made some modifications.

  • The base now requires much less material, cut out some feet instead of a large circle. Also cored out a large portion of the the interior that wasn't needed. This shaved off about 33% of the print time.

  • The first ring also had a fair amount of material shaved off. The ring shrunk inward to be printable on a SM and some holes were added to remove material. Don't know what time savings this added.

  • The top ring had similar holes added to remove extra material and match the first ring design.

I havent added a topper yet. Not sure what direction I will go, but since it will probably just be a mashup of an existing thingiverse figure with the blank top from the K-Cup Tree Frog this is remixed from I probably won't add whatever I do go with to this design.

All three pieces were printed on a stock (with the 'test print' fan shroud added from the setup instructions) Printrbot Simple Metal with Cura using the following settings in PLA:
  • 0.2mm layer height
  • 1mm shell thickness
  • 0.6mm bottom/top thickness
  • 20% fill (probably could have done less on the rings, but with the overhang in the base's core I don't know I would try much less for the base).
  • 40mm/s print speed
  • Brim (think I had to do 10 lines for the first ring, but I did 15 for the base and second ring)
  • Infill speed 50mm/s
  • Travel speed 150mm/s

FYI:
Hatchbox PLA from Amazon @ 205º C. The overhang in the base did have some initial overhang layer problems, but they can't be seen as they are interior. Structurally very sound as I had to really push and pull on the cone to get it off the bed and it held together fine.

comments.text: Printed this on a Flash Forge Creator Pro using ABS and it came out great. I'm going to be making another soon on my new Lulzbot Mini with PETG, will let you know how that one goes.

title: Three Finger Gripper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the first version of the gripper for my robot arm project. I used 3mm carbon fiber rods as shaft. They are cheap easy to cut, strong and light. The motors are 16mm DC geared motors with 180 rmp anything from 100-200 should work fine. They are also quite cheap. To improve the grip I used some rubber foam (in german Mosgummi). You can find all about this project at the hackaday.io project page:
http://hackaday.io/project/3800-3d-printable-robot-arm
or direct at my blog: www.chaozlabs.de and of course my YouTube channel:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeFKz1UJUd5YuxS1ZikqYwA http://youtu.be/pmE4PjirRWE I added the cad files to github:
https://github.com/4ndreas/BetaBots-Robot-Arm-Project/tree/master/ThreeFingerGripper

title: 26 or 18 Point Star Hanging Decoration / Christmas Tree Topper Ornament

description.text: 26 Pointed Star!

Wow, that's a lot of points. If you want to support my projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads. I LEFT THIS AS WORK-IN-PROGRESS not because it's incomplete, but rather 'cause it's a tad finicky. Test a point first to see if it needs scaled and stuff. Options

There are two main options, either the 18 pointed star without the small points, or add the extra 8 small points for an 18 pointed star. A) Print either the normal "center" ball for 26 points, or the "only big points" ball for 18 points.
B) Print it with a mount to fit on a tree, or a point to hang from the ceiling. IMPORTANT Notes on Scale

The model is "supposed" to fit at 100%, however strangeness of the drooping filament might make that tricky as not all of the point mounts are the same size at the same angles.  I had to trim a little drooping bits, and have to glue the points on.  I suggest printing the center first at 100.5% and then one of each point as a test fit.  I used 100% for the big points and 99% for the little points.  
Printing Settings

What worked for me, preview everything to make sure it's behaving. Print the hub and one each big (& little for 26 point star) points, then test the fit before printing the rest of the points. A) Print either the 26 or 18 point center at 100.5% scaling, no rafts or supports, I used 10% infill, .2mm layer height.
  • A couple of the support bits are tricky to remove.
  • I included a version without supports. It'll be a bit droopy, but seemed close enough.
    B) Print 17 big points at 100%, no rafts or supports needed, 2 shells, 10% infill, .2mm layer height.
  • I tested using makerware's slicer, may not work for everyone, please preview. The object is hollow with a double wall to keep the thin walls.
  • Try one point first and see if you want to scale them up/down on your center. My center's bottom holes are "tighter" than the top holes, which meant more filing/exacto kife work.
    C) For the 26 point star, also print 8 of the small triangular points at 99% scale, no rafts or supports, 2 shells, 10% infill, .2mm layer height
  • Try one point first and see if you want to scale them up/down on your center.
    D) Print either the Mount or a Hanging point. Mount fits the same as a big point, so use that scale (100%).
    • Assembly

You can fill the points part way with tinsel or confetti or whatnot, or nothing, and glue them to the center hub.  The hub has a hollow square, so be sure to put that end down if you fill it with stuff, it should either be the center mount or the hanging point should be opposite of that hollow.  Looks cool with a flashlight in the bottom, if you figure out how to light it, let me know!  
Remixed From

Reconstructed from makerbot's star, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:599887. I made several changes.
A) Added additional points on the triangular faces, as if 18 points isn't enough
B) Make the points have holes in the end so confetti or whatever can be added after the fact.
C) Made the center hollow to use less plastic and in case you want to put LEDs or electronics or whatnot in it.
D) Attempted notches for snap fit, but that doesn't really work. Please support my projects

If you want to support my projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads. What worked for me, preview everything to make sure it's behaving. Print the hub and one each big (& little for 26 point star) points, then test the fit before printing the rest of the points. A) Print either the 26 or 18 point center at 101% scaling, no rafts or supports needed, I used 10% infill.
  • If you print at 100%, the little points probably need scaled down.
    B) Print 17 big points at 100% or 101%, no rafts or supports needed, 2 shells, 10% infill.
  • I tested using Makerware's slicer, may not work for everyone, please preview. The object is hollow with a double wall to keep the thin walls.

You can fill the points part way with tinsel or confetti or whatnot, or nothing, and glue them to the center hub.  The hub has a hollow square, so be sure to put that end down if you fill it with stuff, it should either be the center mount or the hanging point should be opposite of that hollow.

title: Walkera Genius CP V2 receiver holder

description.text:
Walkera Genius CP V2 (Exceed X100 V2) replacement Receiver Holder.  
I installed the Walkera brushless upgrade kit on my Exceed X100 V2 and noticed that I had to modify the receiver holder so that it would not hit the motor. I didn't like the way it had to be modified, so I created my own holder using existing holes in the frame. It allows full movement of the motor and fits well under the canopy.  
This will also work with the standard brushed motor too.

extruding speed: 20mm/s (slow for accuracy) Enable raft so it doesn't warp.

remixed_from.author: DDeGonge888
remixed_from.title: [1.5.1] 3uP - Metal H-Bot Upgrade for QUBD Two-Up

description.text: Yes! Finally, a fan bracket for the 3uP which provides cooling to the print with NO LOSS OF PRINT AREA (actually you may possibly lose a tiny square in the front right corner...but close enough!) As I've said before, I would not be making a fan bracket if it meant a loss of print area, but I have finally found a way to work one in, and it works great.

Required Materials 4x M3x20mm Bolts
4x M3 Hex Nuts
1x 40mm 12V Fan This will only work with my custom e3d extruder and the e3d v6 hot end. Use this fan bracket with other setups at your own risk. Print both parts, sandwich the fan in the middle, then bolt the parts together. Be sure to insert the bolts through the duct side first, so that the hex nuts will be the part facing up once the bracket is assembled. Mount it to the bottom right bolt hole on the extruder, using the longer 45mm bolts. note In the images, I only had 25mm bolts on hand. Using 20mm bolts will make it look much cleaner and it will allow you to use bolts in all 4 holes instead of just the bottom 2.

remixed_from.author: mateddy
remixed_from.title: Spool holder using M8 rod and 608ZZ bearing

description.text:
Based on the work of blah_59, I created a version of his threaded rod mounts suitable for 1515 extrusions.
The OpenSCAD file he shared was edited by me. I have also made it compacter and converted it to fit M3 bolts and nuts. I have chosen to use these as mounts for the M8 threaded rod and not the ones that mateddy links to in his instructions.
The reason for this is easy exchange of filament spindles. No need to unscrew the rod, just lift it out of the mounts. [Update 29-03-2015]
I have added an updated version with 2 holes for fastening on the extrusion. It now also has closed sides, so it is impossible for a threaded rod to unscrew itself from the mounts and ruins either your print, diagonal rods, printbed or all of the above... Yes, this happened with me somehow and broke my borosilicate glass. :-(
So when using the open version, make the threaded rod long enough to terminate the rod with an M8 nut. Print the new version double, mirroring the 2nd one for the other side (check for correct axes to mirror!).

For the mounts on the extrusions you need 2x M3 bolt and nut.
Print both a left and right version of the holder. For the universal spool holder you can follow the instructions of mateddy.
I used 250mm M8 threaded rod length for my KosselXL which uses 360mm horizontal extrusions. When you need to make changes to the OpenSCAD file yourself remember to export just one stl and multiply + mirror the copy to create the opposite mount.

title: Simple easy to load quality spool

description.text:
Simple easy to load and strong spool.
Just pop out or pop in the spool.
Mount filament spool on threaded rod with cones and wingnuts.
Slide on bearings.
Drop into place. Very solid !

Print out the cones, the two sides and the base.
use 19mm dia, 6mm wide 8mm hole- bearings.
use 5/16 dia all thread and wingnuts parts are very tight be design. sand where you insert the sides so they are very tight Glue if you want. Small flat bearing holder gets glued to the sides. There is a small ledge to hold it. To mount spool of material use all thread rod- 2 cones- wingnuts and just slide the bearings on and rest into the bearing slots. Very nice spool. For extra wide spools glue 2 bases together and use a longer rod

description.text:
Not just another Brio Railtrack!
This Flextrack can be bend sideways, upways or downways to build curves, bridges and to overcome obstakles!
check out this short clip: http://youtu.be/rw0LYmu16r8 It's designed to be printed in single-line-style!
with superfast printing (300mm/sec @0.24mm) it takes 12min with regular printing (60mm/sec @0.2mm) it takes 35min features:
  • rail track can make 90 degree turns
  • the running surface has extra ziczac's for smooth running
  • the male and female connector do flex-press-fit
  • it's lightweight and quite rigid!
    • this thing was made in tinkerCAD, go remix it! http://goo.gl/yPv6ve UPDATE:
    I made an extralong version! 195mm! Should still fit into most 3D Printers...
    here's the tinkerCAD link: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cEqGDwNPmII-brioflexrailextralong/ UPDATE:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=csqDdcoJBkI
    New Video: Extra long Version, Printed with strong PLA-HI (https://creamelt.com/?product=creamelt-pla-hi-blue&lang=en)

for printing, i used the spiralize-option in cura, but you also can also just print without infill and a single-wall setup (optimized for 0.4mm nozzle)
i also used 20% more flow as the standard setting. you can print this thing very fast, there is no part where it needs to be super precise...

comments.text: This is brilliant and one of my favorite things I've printed so far. I've adapted it to Trackmaster (old style) tracks by editing the SCAD file, trying to maintain the vase mode printing. I've been mostly successful but run into trouble around the cutout (female end). How did you avoid the slicer adding extra blobs around the cutout? Your STL clearly has extra material around the cutout that doesn't divide evenly into extrusion width. But your resulting print evidently didn't have anything in those spaces. I've tried Slic3r, Prusa Slic3r, Cura, and Simplify3d and they all add extra blobs to fill in those spaces. And the real problem is that those extra blobs interfere with the vase mode and cause non-printing traversals (not sure whether it retracts first) across the entire track.

Often time Stuffhub wonders what else 3D printing can bring to our lives. This time we use 3d printing to create customized molds and partnered with a local candy shop, the papabubble, to make these lovely lollipops. Here’s how we do it:

  • Create a 3d printed object you want (text, shape or company logos). Or use the one I uploaded.

  • Use food grade silicone to cast the mold. There are plenty options on Amazon. It’s fairly easy, just follow the instruction.

  • Put candy in the mold while it is still hot.
    • I think hard candy is relatively difficult to make at home, but the same mold can also used for chocolate. Hope it is still in time for Valentine's. Update:
    Here is a short youtube video of how we make these lollipop. (http://youtu.be/Dk0Y-DQqxLM)

An adapter lid that turns a regular mason jar into a sauce packet harvester! We all have random piles of sauce packets lining our kitchen drawers. Everything from hot sauce to those weird little room temp mayo packets (gross!). Nobody ever uses them, because it's tedious work to tear open those annoying buggers one after another. Let's admit it, those cat pictures on the internet need to be looked at. You can't waste valuable time cursing at those little envelopes of free food. Enter the "AWESOME SAUCE"! Simply fasten the lid to any regular mouth mason jar, place the offending little packets in the receptacle, and press down on the spiked plunger! If you're a horrible sociopath like me, just pretend the little packets are your whimpering enemies(or, stay sane and don't do that...your call) Now, you have a jar full of free sauce! In fact, mix it up and just smash every random packet in your kitchen at the same time! Make a custom sauce to amaze your friends and confuse your enemies. http://youtu.be/kqEgSC7uKNU

Print out pieces at 40% or more infill for strength. Check fit of lid item to regular mason jar. Adjust print settings as needed. Assemble by fastening lid to mason jar, and then place a sauce packet in the receptacle area.
Align plunger indicator mark with mark on the lid. Press slowly and deliberately. This will pierce the sauce packet, and empty it's contents into the jar. Try not to think of enemies or former lovers when doing so. It just gets weird, man...

My wife is a physical therapists that works with kids with special needs and wounded warriors. She supports and volunteers time with an organization called AMBUCS that provides mobility to these special people. In order to fit the user to the bike or trike they need they use demo equipment that gets a lot of use and abuse. One of the trikes had broken and so my wife thought I needed a new "project". I love a challenge so I jumped in to help.  
I had seen 123D Designer and it looked like a nice design tool so I spent a couple of evenings learning the software and then jumped into the design of the replacement part. It was relatively easy except for some of the dimensioning. It can be a challenge in 123D. I hope they add to it's capabilities because it is a very friendly design tool. I like it!  
The black piece is the broken part. It holds a 4ft long steel tube with a handle on the end that is used to control the trike during the demo with up to a 40lb child on it so it can have quite a bit of stress. I made the replacement part out of silver PLA. Only time will tell if it is strong enough. I did pick up the trike and move it around and felt flexing in the plastic handle more than the replacement part. If it does break I can have another one made in about 8 hours.  
You may notice a seam in the part. That was because during the print I touched the frame of my printer and heard the unmistakable sound of a static discharge spark........the print job stopped six hours into the print. I used Cura to cut the original part so that I could print just the upper section. Some careful sanding and CA glue and the parts were joined together. If it fails then I will just print another. The glue joint is not in a high stress area so it should be fine.  
The last two pictures are of the latest prints. Two more to go to fix more trikes.
Latest update: I've made about a dozen of these and they have been sent all over the world! They have held up very well with only one that was a problem. That spool of PLA gave me some print issues so that was most likely the issue.
Designed with 123D. Printed on my modified K8200 using .2mm layers, 50% infill, PLA.

comments.text: It was not the first time for me either. Breaking designs into smaller parts actually saves time!

comments.text: I sympathize with you on that seam. I had to do that several times over a 40hr print job... now I slice my large objects into MUCH smaller parts.

This is a replacement case for the Choosatron Deluxe Adventure Matrix. This has not been test printed as yet. If you print this and it works fine, please comment. The picture is of the original Choosatron case, not my replacement.

Print all parts using a high infill setting for strength.
Parts may be a tight fit and require sanding to fit together smoothly. The original Choosatron case has clips that snap off easily. Those have been removed and screw holes put in their place. Eight small screws should hold it together well. Note, I haven't test printed this as yet, however it has been meticulously lined up in Tinkercad to ensure all parts fit. Most parts should replace any existing ones you have. I'll keep this noted as a Work-in-progress until it is test printed and all parts fit together. Replacement button pads can be purchased on ebay or DX. Ebay: http://bit.ly/1zJ5xj4 (one unit)
Ebay: http://bit.ly/1CZuxlJ (Five units)
DX: http://bit.ly/1wOSQvr (Five units) Reference only, I haven't purchased from any of the ebay links.

I found that I was burning through tons of zipties attaching and detaching my fan from my printer, but I didn't want to go through the hassle of bolting and unbolting it with a bolt, so I designed a push-clip style nut that pushes in and snaps into place.

I got this idea from RVJET pocket hatches: by boopidoo. This is a
work in progress. But I have finally made it to the last stages. The
mount fits into the pocket of the RVJET, but some foam
modifications are necessary. I made this to be able to clip in the
front and screw in the back with plastic screws into a base plate.
Mine is made in natural color as I did not have any more black. But it is made just to show
you the end result. The screws and nuts that I
used can be bought at your local hardware store. I believe they were 6-32 plastic screws
and nuts. The front base plate and the rear bolt
base plate needs to be glued or epoxied in. I will be making some
changes after I test this. I am not sure the front scoop is deep
enough, as it doesn't match the size of the exit inverted scoop.

Once printed just cut the support out under the front tab and the
foam out a little to fit the 2 base plates and the main cover into the
foam while keeping it flush. Also drill out the holes with a 3.5mm drill bit .I did find out that the wing is curved at the front so instead of
trying to figure out the exact curve of the wing I just used my heat
gun to soften the front piece ahead of the scoop and gave it the
proper curve. You will
need to buy the plastic screws and nuts, I believe they were 6-32.
The nuts fit perfect into the printed base. Then glue/epoxy the 2
base plates in and then it just fits together. Take your time cutting
out the foam, so you will have a beautiful fit: unlike my first one as
seen in the picture.
My second one came out perfect.

comments.text: They look great and work well, but are a little bit longer than the pockets; to get them to sit flush with the wing you need to cut some extra foam out. If you take the foam from the trailing edge side of the pockets, you run the risk of accidentally cutting into your servo wires. I got lucky and didn't cut the wires, but they are now exposed in the pocket. It's probably better or safer to ground these on trailing edge of the pocket and cut the extra foam from the leading edge of the pocket.
comments.author: scottthomas

comments.text: Thanks you for your comments.  I did make them so you had to cut into the foam so they would sit flush and I also had to cut back into the servo channel but I just rerouted the wires. I am working on another version that will follow the body better, maybe I can address the other issue also.
comments.author: scottthomas

comments.text: It's certainly not an issue, they look good. It was just a surprise when I exposed the servo wires; I'm happy I didn't slice them. Just wanted to put the comment here so that someone else doesn't end up cutting their wires.
comments.author: donandtheresa

description.text:
UPDATE: I am learning more about Slic3r; I realized that instead of stopping the print manually that I could set the top layer to 0.... and let the print finish with no top surface. So I shortened the cookie to 3.35mm, set top layer to 0 for a new set of files, labeled V2. Same end result with less work on your part.
Note, the G-Code files are set for printing PLA. I also added the updated STL file. I made these honeycomb-infill density sample cookies as a visual printing aid for myself.
There is a "generic" STL file, and 9 G-Code files for 0.1 - 0.9 infill densities.
I printed with 4 base layers and stopped the prints at the end of the 3.15mm height.
These may also work with a 1-2 top and bottom layer, I just did not try printing them that way.

remixed_from.author: random11
remixed_from.title: Master Ball, with magnetic clasp (Fixed Lid)

description.text:
The only thing I changed from the "Master Ball, with magnetic clasp" was the lid again.  
Print the two lid files. Lib_Black wont need supports but Lid_Yellow may. After printing the parts you should be able to easily assemble the lid. From there glue the button into the button holder. Then glue the button assembly and the ring to the bottom with the hinge in place as you glue the ring down. Then snap the hinge into the lid.  
You will need 2 magnets (1/4" X 1/16") and just glue them in place.  
Tip: Print your bottom piece at a higher in fill percentage, around 40-50% and then all the other parts at 5-10%. That way it will be bottom heavy and not roll around as much.
